title: Clique: only one transaction recorded per block
body:
#### System information

Geth version: `1.6.1`
OS & Version: OSX 10.12.5

#### Expected behaviour

Multiple transactions are recorded in a block when submitted by WS-RPC

#### Actual behaviour

There is only one transaction per block

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour

Repeatedly submit transaction via WS RPC

#### Backtrace

As you can see from the geth logs below, multiple transactions are submitted rapidly but sequentially between two blocks. Only one transaction is recorded per block.

This node is *not* a miner

Please check the gas limit you provided to your transactions and the block's limit. If a transaction's requested gas doesn't fit into the block after executing some (1?) tx, it will not be attempted to be squeezed in.

@karalabe Hi Péter. That the total gas spent does not exceed the block gas limit makes total sense.

However the gas limit in the genesis block is set to 0x47b760 (4700k) while each transaction submitted above consumes about 1354k gas. I would therefore expect that 3 of these transactions would fit in every block. Other transactions consuming about 577k are generated by another node, and these could fit in too, but do not.

Having the node mine blocks does not change the behaviour. I am still getting a single transaction per block.

Note: having run the same transactions on a "standard" PoW private network (i.e. not Clique) of the same size using Geth v1.5.8, I have seen multiple transactions fit in a block.

(As a side question: since this is a permissioned network where gas consumption does not matter, is there a way to disable gas calculations entirely or force it to some arbitrary value ?)

It may consume 1354k gas, but how mach are you giving it when you submit the tx? That i the main driving force when trying to figure out if it fits or not. Also the block limit of the genesis isn't that interesting, rather what's it at currently (you can retrieve it via `eth.getBlock("latest")`).

Gas consumption does matter as that is the one ensuring transactions don't run indefinitely. It's the mechanism guaranteeing timing constraints. There's no way to disable gas metering currently though, a lot of consensus critical code relies on gas calculations.

Thanks for the explanation.
The latest block gas limit value is close to the genesis block value: 4712k
I confirm that lowering the submitted gas from a value close to the block limit to a value close to the transaction gas consumption value (i.e 1500k)  "solves" the problem and I can "stick" 3 transactions in a block.

There is therefore no technical issue per se, however, please understand that in a B2B scenario - where I (and my company) see a lot of value for Clique - this requirement may make transacting data extremely difficult as it prevents scaling.

Say you want to write a Purchase Order in the ledger. The number of purchased item lines may vary from one PO to another. Transacting these POs will therefore lead to different gas consumption due to different data size. Since it is close to impossible to pre-estimate the gas consumption and you want to avoid failing transactions, the only "safe" strategy is to submit a lot of gas. This in turn will reduce the number of transactions per block and then seriously limit the total transactions that can be processed in a given amount of time, assuming a reasonable heartbeat for blocks.

The only strategy I see at the moment is to
1- create a genesis block with with a ridiculously high gas limit  (what is the max btw ?)
2- hope the latest/current block is close to that limit (why should not it be ?)
3- submit transactions with gas that you know will cover any data size
(4- hope that future VM releases do not lead to higher gas consumptions)

Can you suggest an alternative ?

(since there is no technical problem as such, please feel free to close that issue)

@bgrieder You can estimate the gas before sending the transaction  (I usually increase it by 10% ). Using `web3js` https://web3js.readthedocs.io/en/1.0/web3-eth-contract.html#methods-mymethod-estimategas
